review_title: Great Place to Build Research Skills
job_title: Junior Data Scientist in Glendale, CA
pros: Amazing team of data scientists. You learn on the job pretty fast. Collaborated with VPICU for additional training. Flexible work hours. Decent pay (not exactly market rate, but good enough). The doctors and clinicians are amazing people to collaborate with for research projects. Benefits are pretty good. They match up to 4% on retirement ( I think) We didn't work at the hospital, but we were placed in an office in Glendale.
cons: Not too many cons, except you aren't payed at the same rate as the market. Also the boss of the TSRI data science group at the time over works his employees. VPICU group has more balance.

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner III in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Great culture but salary is not
job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Los Angeles, CA

job_title: Research Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are some incredibly kind, compassionate, and hard working doctors, nurses, and researchers that work at CHLA. The Cafeteria is basically a 5 star restaurant.
cons: I have never witnessed the type of excessive bullying in any organization in my life. HR will receive repeated compliments about sever work place bullying about a specific supervisor from numerous people and will simply go through the motions of "an investigation" but never actually implement any form of action to remedy the situation. They sit back as multiple research coordinators are the targets of retaliation and will do absolutely nothing about it. If you come to work here, you are not protected against being screamed out in front of countless coworkers, managers talking poorly about you to other colleagues, and punishing you for speaking up about being mistreated.

review_title: CHLA is a great organization to work in

job_title: Researcher in Hollywood, CA
pros: The employees have an extreme amount of empathy for the patients and their families that they truly work for. Patients can find a hospital that is ready to bill their insurance, and sometimes have very little choice in going anywhere else.
cons:
I have been an employee for several years now. I decided to work for a charity/mid sized hospital for what everyone told me would be a wonderful and empathetic experience. Instead I have dealt with MDs with a god complex, Employee health and HR department only interested in covering the company, and a management team that takes the term subpar to a new and far lower level. Upon starting there I received so little training I couldn't find my own office much less be given the appropriate tools to do my job. I've been stalked by another employee and watched that very same employee be promoted even after escalating it to HR. You want to hear a worse scenario, my supervisors afterwards retaliated against me while flooding me with work to distract me. My opinion, avoid this place, they will hold anyone back from development, and after three reviews with no information on how I can grow, I decided to submit the same review from the previous year, no one noticed, what a farce.

Stay away!

job_title: Financial Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The people that work at this institution overall has a very welcoming energy. My Journey was truly pleasant.
cons: Lacking in the area of teamwork between clinical and admin.

job_title: Staff RN in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great Facility and has all the newest equipment.  The doctors are very approachable and work well with the staff.
cons: Management is completely unaware of the staff and their needs.  Doesn't value talent and hard work, only concerned with metrics and numbers.  They are not approachable and when given advice appear to completely ignore it.  It has been observed by many staff members that management slows career progression of staff trying to keep them trapped in the positions they are in and play favorites consistently.  If you want to be anything more than a bedside care giver this is not the place for you there is no room for growth especially for minorities.

review_title: Childrens Hospital Los Angeles is a wonderful place to work, grow and learn.
job_title: Registered Nurse I in Los Angeles, CA

cons: One of the challenges of working at CHLA is that some units are favored over others. I think this may have to do with managers and managerial styles as well as the ability of managers to advocate for their staff. I think you probably find this anywhere though, it is not uncommon.

review_title: Not an ideal company for post-doctorate research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
great location
most co-workers are easy to get along with if they don't have an ego problem
excellent doctors and staff
opportunity for collaboration with several different research groups
support staff - janitors, electricians, animal facility employees are very nice and will accommodate your requests
cons:
this company is all about the money - if you can't bring it in, then you are let go
needs more research funding
prepare to spend most of your time writing grants with little left for research
internal post-doc research grant funding is very competitive
stressful atmosphere
parking is horrible - I use public transportation
open lab design can make it hard to concentrate especially when you have people from other labs entering or passing through your lab space
needs to have a more reasonable salary considering how expensive it is to live in Los Angeles

review_title: Great insight into the dynamics of politics between administration and clinical / contracted medical employees.
job_title: Administration in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Great entry level opportunities depending on which department/division you are in.

Some clincial leaders are outwardly supportive of their administrative support.
cons:
Match contribution program is not comparable to market.  Standard vested program.

Unfortunately administrative managers play favorites with support staff.  Unfounded/unsubstantiated complaints make their way to HR and ultimately leave a poor reflection across all of CHLA (with regard to low-to-mid level operations & administration and managers thereof).

Training for administration, especially external resources, are not widely supported and opportunities are rare.

job_title: IT Department in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
CHLA's mission is second to none.
Most of the staff will do a much as they can for the patients and the clinical staff.
Pay was pretty good. Some leaders, now gone, tried to make it right.
cons:
Almost entire IT leadership team has been laid off or left after current CIO returned to CHLA in October. Multiple "Reorgs" reducing leadership staff by over 15 directors. Heard the new CTO that just hired on in March  resigned already. That's 2 CIO's and now 3 CTO's since September. CIO seems to be making change for the sake of change with no apparent direction. 
HR is not an employee friend
POLITICS AND EGOS

job_title: Clinical Researcher in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
CHLA recognizes the hard work each employee contributes in making the institution worthy of the recognition it has been given by families and communities it has served and are continuously serving. CHLA has a friendly and family-like culture.

Employees are treated with respect, voices are heard and needs are recognized.
cons: It is to be expected that CHLA has it's own share of flaws as there is no such thing as a perfect or ideal workplace. For an employee impacted by such flaws, it's either you a) don't do anything and continue to whine about it, or b) identify those flaws and help to correct them.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Childrens Hospital Los Angeles has a good reputation and working for Childrens is highly respected by others.
Working to help fighting disease is extremely satisfactory.
The open floor plan of the research building allows for a lot of collaboration and communication  between members of different groups.
cons:
Like with most postdoctoral fellow jobs in academia, the pay is extremely low and makes it hard to survive in a place like Los Angeles.
The open floor plan of the research building leads to quite a bit of chaos and people of other labs might randomly use your equipment and stuff.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The location, in Los Angeles.
cons: Poor pay (a letter from HR dated 8/16/2015 states 96% of employees are below market rate), Management heavy, Kaiser attitude to research, poor benefits, no advancement, more bureaucracy than you can shake a stick at, each year loses rank (was number 4 in 2000, now number 8). Also inadequate parking,

review_title: Poor work-life balance and below-market pay
job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There is a certain prestige of working for this organization. You also receive discounts in the cafeteria and gift shop.
cons:
Compensation is well below market value, especially considering the high cost of living in Los Angeles. 

If you are a salaried employee, the work-life balance is poor. It is expected of you to provide for your patients at all times. Admin support is extremely limited. 

There is no money for continuing education. You have to pay to attend conferences even if you are a presenter. 

The management structure makes no sense.

review_title: My dream job! I'm a lifer for sure.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Best thing is the team work oriented environment, you'll never feel like you're drowning and no one wants to help. Staff education, focus on evidence based practice, collaborative governance, employee participation, all these are huge pros to working at CHLA. Management is always available to you, and they truly care about you as an employee.
cons: Pay can be better, especially with the rising cost of living. The parking situation can definitely improve.

review_title: Childrens Hospital Los Angeles is a great place to work!!
job_title: Finance in Los Angeles, CA
pros: One of the best reasons to work for Childrens Hospital is that everyone is working for a greater cause. Everyone is also willing to put in extra time and energy when deadlines are tight and others need help. The ability to telecommute a couple of days a week is also a plus.
cons: There is quite a bit of work and projects to complete and sometimes it seems as there is not enough time or people to meet deadlines and get things done. There can also be unrealistic deadlines set for when projects are to be completed and conflicts can arise when something isn't finished on time.

job_title: ACF Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: CHLA is a prestigious hospital on the cutting edge of providing the best care for the most complex medical cases.
cons: Pay is not sufficient to survive living any kind of life in Los Angeles.  Not even close.  Really bad when over half of your monthly check goes to pay rent.  That leaves you with half of a check for a month.  No can do.  But they tell us that we are very important, greatly appreciated, and the operation couldn't function without us.  That's nice.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I'm part of a supportive department that encourages growth. The hospital seems to value what we do. Great people on staff overall. I believe in the mission and dedication to children and families. Overall, as "fun" an atmosphere as you can get, given that it's a hospital treating kids with serious illnesses.
cons: Salaries are not the highest you will find, but they are getting more competitive in an effort to retain talent.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Obviously this is a children's hospital so it's expected that you are working with children, but really, that what it comes down to. People work here for the kids. Many of my co-workers are also pretty awesome. Also, it's worth working here as an RN just to be able to be a part of their Residency program, as you are really supported and come to the floor as prepared as you can be without being a seasoned RN. Also, since it's a children's hospital in Los Angeles, you will definitely see some famous folk if you work day shifts. It's just one of those fun perks.
cons:
The hourly pay is terrible. I'm talking $6-10 less an hour compared to other area hospitals. And that's excluding the hospitals like UCLA and Kaiser that have above-average pay. Also, the compensation for continuing education is laughable (something like $300 a semester for getting a Master's degree), and there is no student loan repayment program to speak of. The benefits are mediocre at best, and they even do wonderful things like limit you from getting any further raises after you've been with the company for some time. Who does that?? Inflation obviously means nothing to CHLA. 

You will work every other weekend for around 10 years, depending on the unit, and quite a few holidays. My unit spends most of its time trying to figure out staffing, since there is quite a bit of turnover (obviously that varies between units), and management in general leaves something to be desired. When you have three different managers and one is great while two are awful, expect nothing of note to get accomplished. Maybe it's like this anywhere, but many of my co-workers are in a constant state of complaint about managers, meager salaries, and the TERRIBLE traffic. There is always hushed discussion of looking for and applying to new jobs.

I have contacted payroll more times than I'd like to think about to get paychecks corrected, and they have this wonderful way of either not responding at all, or saying that the error will be corrected on the next pay check, 2 weeks from now. When you are missing over $1,000 dollars it can be important for it to be fixed in a timely manner.

Oh, and how could we forget the parking? I have actually seen several accidents in the parking structures at CHLA.

job_title: Registered Nurse II, BSN in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Floor nurses are supported on the hematology/ oncology floor where I work, with great ratios. We're typically 3:1, almost never 4:1, and sometimes 2:1 with very sick patients.  We have IV team 24/7, respiratory therapists, a resource RN 24/7, care partners (nursing assistants) staffed at 8:1 max, and dedicated charge nurses that don't take patient assignments. Your co-workers will also support you. Everyone believes in the mission here, and generally looks out for each other.  Morale is typically high and people are kind and accepting towards each other. 

We also get breaks here, don't let anyone tell you otherwise! More than one, too ;)

There are also plenty of "extra" things to get involved in (councils and committees, audits, research, etc.), and there are a lot of ways the hospital tries to make nurses feel cared for and heard (HR night rounds, occasional face to face meetings with the CNO or CEO, etc.).

The night shift differential is good, $4.75 for 1st 4 hours and $8 for the last 8. That comes out to around $7/hour overall, close to $1000/month.
cons:
Those "extra" things are an expectation to receive raises that are still less than the average rate of inflation. New RNs get brought up to speed in terms of pay fairly quickly but after a few years you're looking at a around 1.5% yearly increase if you work your butt off on the "extras", and less than 1% if you don't get involved much off of the floor. You will always be told you're "above market" after 3 or 4 years of experience and will not get raises with market adjustments.

The benefits are marginal. They do match your 401k contributions at 3% after a year, regardless of your status (full time, per diem, etc.). But health insurance is pretty blah. My husband's offerings through work are better and cheaper even at his part time status versus my full time. 

Also, if you're part time here (less than 0.75 FTE for the sake of benefits), be prepared for your health insurance premiums to be nearly double the full time rate. There is also no way to waive your benefits and take a slightly higher pay rate, so don't ask. LA is expensive, and many nurses here work a second job or pick up extra shifts beyond being full time to be able to afford it.

Aside from the expectations of much  involvement beyond the "floor" for any RN, there is unfortunately not much of a clinical ladder. The desirable roles (lead RNs, managers, house supervisors, directors) are filled by people that do not tend to leave for decades. So for job growth, if that's your thing, RNs tend to go back to school and become NPs, teach, or find positions elsewhere. Not much room on the ladder here. They'll be happy for you to take on more work in councils, etc. but it won't likely earn you any promotions because everybody is in the same boat.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: CHLA reputation as being a leader in pediatric medicine.  Being part of this great organization for 25+ years, it has been a privilege to be part of their strategic initiatives in making it a top facility.
cons: I would say it would be too many initiatives at once and you are not allowed to breathe between one go-live to the next.  Extremely busy. Space them out a little.

review_title: great mission but a terrible employee culture with rampant bullying and favoritism
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great employees - conscientuous and dedicated
cons: Some leaders say they don’t want to hear complaints - therefore, employees have stopped communicating as a result.  NOT good stewards of the resources available to them - especially employees - no work/life balance - physicians run the hospital and promote only those who support their objectives - very resistant to change.  Some leaders there for decades with strong politics and no desire to change.  NOT good stewards of financial resources - SAVE your money or be specific about how it is to be spent!

job_title: Marketing in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Management that sincerely cares about the wellbeing of employees.
- Leadership team that constantly assesses processes and looks for new ways to improve.
- Fun, meaningful projects. 
- Company culture.
- Great co-workers.
- Nationally-ranked hospital.
cons: This hospital treats some of the sickest and most seriously injured children, many of whom are hospitalized for a long time. This can be heartbreaking work. But also beautiful and powerful. Watching sick kids grow stronger and stronger everyday is a good reminder of why we do what we do. Every role at this hospital has the opportunity to make a difference.

job_title: LVN in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Acute and ambulatory experience. 
Renowned pediatric hospital. 
Roth 401k and 403b
Paid time off
Vacation and sick pay
Most holidays off
Free dental and great vision plans
cons:
The divisions (departments) run their own units, a lot of politics and in many cases cattiness across the board.
Everyone looks unhappy walking down the hall. You smile no smile backs.
Pay is not competitive and many times offer less than other institutions.
Health insurance is expensive and mediocre for price.

job_title: Research Specialist II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Work with great minds from across the world.  Contribute to a worthwhile cause in pediatric medicine.  Los Angeles is a great city to live and work.
cons: Pay is mediocre, even after a market increase to make wages fair, most lower positions still below average, especially for a city with an enormous cost of living.  In addition, employees have additional roles dumped on them, doing the work of multiple people and positions well above current job titles, but somehow no change in compensation.  Benefits are horrible, very expensive(~15% of salary), come out of your "base salary", and have astronomical deductions for the coverage and amount paid.  The same coverage can be obtained through Covered California at the same or even lower rates. On the research end, space and equipment are very limited.  Most equipment is outdated and barely functioning.  Available core services are less-than-helpful.  Must travel to USC to receive any meaningful help.  Researchers are very opinionated and many investigators are downright rude.  Collaboration is difficult and deceit is rampant.  Long story short, nothing is ever good enough here.  The more you do, the more is expected of you, but don't expect your compensation to keep up.  You will have many roadblocks thrown in your way but little help in overcoming them.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing nursing staff with a passion for their patients.  Family focused environment with the goal to make being in a hospital as easy as possible.
cons: Mass exodus of top leadership resulting in promotion of staff unprepared to lead and hiring of individual senior leaders not part of a "team."   It's sad to see the progress made over the last several years dismantled so quickly.  Mood Elevator way low there...

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I believe the care provided to children is excellent, however, some departments do not respond promptly to appointment requests.  Many employees are friendly, good people.
cons: Salaries are comparatively low and receiving even a cost of living raise is totally dependent on whether an employee's supervisor bothers to do a review.  Some high level executives treat their staff very badly and favoritism is rampant in many departments.

review_title: Good Work Life Balance, Benefits, But No Performance Based Pay Increases Due to Ineffective Performance Review System
job_title: Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This review is for the hospital's IT Dept. only.  Competitive medical, dental, vision, and vacation benefits.  Work/Life balance; team works from home on Friday. Free company paid training available to IT staff.
cons: High turnover of talented software engineering talent due to ineffective performance review rating system with no established baseline criteria or performance guidelines.  High performance evaluations and professional accomplishments go unacknowledged and unrewarded by current disengaged management who view IT staff as replaceable & make no effort to identify, reward or retain talented IT staff.  This has resulted in a high turnover rate of talented software engineering talent including a Data Architect and a Team lead. Under the current rating system, IT staff are rated based on subjective ambiguous, unquantifiable criteria, and only if their professional accomplishments are "rated" above average would they be considered for a raise.  Since no guidelines have been established for quantitatively defining when a software engineer completes a task at the higher range level, software engineering professional accomplishments go unrewarded. There is no guidance provided.  This prevents anyone from getting higher ratings and therefore a pay raise because the person who evaluates the ratings hasn't provided their judgment, and so in withholding rating criteria, is being ambiguous and limiting.  Therefore, the hospital's software engineers do not know what they need to do to earn higher ratings.

job_title: Administrative Staff in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I love the dept that I work for as well as the people that I work with. My immediate supervisor is wonderful.
cons: Salary is very much on the low side compared to other hospitals. Pay increases are not given. Clinical staff receive quarterly bonuses while the administrative staff are given a 3% COLA once a yr. Apparently this year there is a “freeze” and we may not get a COLA.

review_title: A welcoming place to work where employees are dedicated to the mission statement.
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The atmosphere at CHLA is very welcoming and you can tell that all employees are there for one sole cause: the children. Whether it is a physician or a member of administrative staff, everyone does their daily job on behalf of bettering the hospital and the car it provides to its patients.
cons: Since it is such a large hospital with a deep history, many conflicting opinions exist in the workplace. However, this is natural in such a setting and the staff at CHLA work hard to maintain a professional and inviting work environment despite occasional conflicts.

review_title: Great organization, but always room for improvement!

pros: Mission-driven organization that seeks to provide great care to underserved populations. Great co-workers and working environment. Decent pay and benefits.
cons:
The organization recruits people with graduate-level education to work coordinator positions that are very clerical in nature and offer little upward mobility. This often leads to very high turnover rates and low job satisfaction.

Politics are a huge issue here. If you are not part of the "in" crowd you are at a disadvantage.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Hospital has a high reputation, the staff care about th epatients and are fun to be with. They have a new $635 million state of the art facility, which has some of the latest technologies and equipment.
cons:
Promotion within departments are not entirely based on performance or work load, its 'who you know and who knows you'
Difficult to find interdepartmental opportunities.

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist III in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Your customers are the best reason to work at CHLA.  Everyone wants to help kids so everyone works at their best to make them better!  The satisfaction you get from knowing you've helped a child get better or go home early is priceless!
cons: Unfortunately, not the most high paying in the area.  Both neighboring hospitals pay more.  Top heavy, need more indians and less chiefs.

cons: Quite a bit of responsibility to take on directly out of undergrad, and had to get used to a hospital environment, which was very different from college.

review_title: Love the people who work here

cons: There is so much change in healthcare right now that it's a chaotic time. There are so many projects to take on that it can affect patient care. Sometimes the communication about why we are doing these things isn't there.

review_title: An employer with a worthy mission, but not without its share of turbulent turnovers.

cons: For most employees, the retirement "program" consists of only 3% matching of 401k contributions.  Some departments are commonly though to be stingy regarding salaries, sometimes going years without cost-of-living adjustments (COLAs) to match inflation.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The staff is great with each other. No matter which floor you are on, you feel like you are part of a team. Everyone is incredibly competent. I have never worked with better nurses.
cons: Benefits have dwindled over the years. Pay is much lower than you can get for other facilities in the area. Education reimbursement is laughable.

review_title: This is one of the best, my daughter has kidney failure and she always went there and I do need to say, they are the .

job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Los Angeles, CA

cons: The only complaint I had during my time there was a period with a nurse manager who was very aggressive in his style, the Human Resource Department was not useful or receptive to the problems being reported by staff.

job_title: Research Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very challenging environment since I work in a lab. I also got to meet a lot of people outside my lab personnel. Working in a hospital brings you closer to patients and gives you the drive to work harder
cons: Since I am part of the lab requests by the lab are not processed too soon which is understnadable since it is a hospital

review_title: Mission is wonderful! Great place to fundraise
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Inglewood, CA
pros: Great Team, nice family atmosphere in our team
cons:
Extremely difficult to get time off.
Pay is lousy.  People who hardly work or have no clue what they are doing seem to be able to get higher pay.
No professional development for non-clinical staff

job_title: Medical Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good environment. Good reputation and good place to get experience. I love being a part of a team that cares for its patients.
cons: The benefits are expensive and the pay is not that great, LA is and expensive place to live In or drive to, we should get paid more. I expected more from a hospital.

job_title: Staff RN in Hollywood, CA
pros: Challenging, complex patients, intelligent coworkers, new facility, many opportunities for collaboration and research. Always seeing something new, learning something new.
cons: Challenging to get vacation time approved, consistently dealing with catty coworkers and lead nurses that make life hard just to make life hard

review_title: Great Place to Work; High Expectations
job_title: Psychologist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You will always feel like you are making a difference. Everybody is very dedicated to our patients. The workplace is happy and respectful.
cons: The expectations are very high, exempt employees work long hours, and some of the compensation is lower than comparable pediatric hospitals in Southern California.

job_title: Program Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: it offeres great work life balance, no stress, lots of freedom. There are no timelines and unclear deliverable needs
cons: *lots* of politics - as the pros are that you do not have to accomplish anything, it does mean that accomplishing things do not make you more successful.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Happy work environment, you leave work knowing you made an impact on a child's life and his family. Overall good health benefits for the employee but not for the family.
cons: No raise beside the 2% COLA(Cost of Living) yearly. Difficult to obtain a promotion within the same department.

review_title: Serving as key professional in Health information management.
job_title: Scanning Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: CHLA is one of top ranking hospital in the world, Though the job is contractual but helped me to gather new knowledge on health information management.
cons: so far no downsides observed or experienced just because of short term contract. A long term employment will give a perfect assessment of the institution.

job_title: Contract Sourcing Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Its a prestigious hospital and good for resume. Also helps children get better.
cons: Bad benefits and the people are so bad to work with all over the company.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great place if what you're looking for something while seeking a better job
cons: Was forced to do someone's work and she presented it as her own. New CEO should re-think his support staff.

review_title: The atmosphere ranges from enjoyable to difficult depending on your supervisor.
job_title: Program Administrator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Helping sick children is always rewarding.
cons: No set processes or systems in place. Most employees work by what they've been taught. This leads to a lot of inconsistencies.

review_title: Fabulous medical care for kids, administrative culture needs work
job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Being part of an institution that provides excellent clinical care to sick kids -- largely from disadvantaged populations
cons: Very hierarchy oriented -- difficult to have influence unless a "top" administrator who is also a doctor or C-suite business person. Limited willingness to accept creative ideas or drive change.

job_title: Intern in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Open atmosphere, kind, driven co-workers who are passionate about making a difference in the lives of those who come to Children's Hospital Los Angeles
cons: The internship was unpaid, and the tasks were at times monotonous. However, I did have a handful of tasks that I maintained ownership of and would have preferred more guidance.

job_title: Care Partner in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They love teaching and are so patient with new staff. I love the amount of teamwork on the units and highly encouraged communication with one another.
cons: There is a lot of orientation requirements and paperwork once hired, but I'm sure it's like that anywhere you go.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Big hospital with lots of resources. If you need anything to assist with the services provided, you can get it.
cons: Some of the medical doctors can be condescending to other professional doctors (non-MDs). CHLA is very political with some MDs who hold a lot of power because they came from prestigious universities.

job_title: Food Service Cook in Fontana, CA
pros: The pay is great, most co-workers are amazing. You can do most of the positions blind folded.
cons: The management is the worst I've ever dealt with, they constantly fail to keep to their word, causing people to constantly leave.

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great competent staff. I really enjoy working here. The doctors are great
cons: The cons are sick kids. I wish all babies where born healthy and didn't have to be in the hospital.

review_title: Best place to work! High job satisfaction!
job_title: Pediatric RN in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Top pediatric hospital nationwide. Teamwork atmosphere. MD and RN residency available for new graduates and new pediatric doctors - highly competitive but intense training to produce top nurse and doctors.
cons: Pay slightly low compared to nearby hospitals in area.

job_title: Pharmacist II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are ups and downs to each job. The people make it worth it here. They are wonderful!
cons: Really? I have to put cons. I wouldn't want to work with arya. I don't think that would be fair to anyone. Other than that. Great people.

review_title: Some departments are better than others.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great doctors, research programs, and patient mix. HOPE program is so valuable.
cons: Employees are hired to fill positions then suddenly let go when replacements are found. Ineffective communication from HR and management (department supervisors). Management listens to employee cliques, not to patient care / customer reviews.

review_title: Overall, great people but politics get in the way
job_title: Project Leader in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great opportunity to move up if in the right department. Good compensation and supportive environment for those starting out in healthcare.
cons: Depending on the department, a great deal of politics that slow down projects.

review_title: Best Place to Work - hands down
job_title: Registered Nurse in Buena Park, CA
pros: Every one here supports and helps each other. None of the nurses "eat their young"
cons: Definitely the pay, but we do it for the kids <3

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Friendly and down to earth, easy access to managers and directors. Great compensation and health benefits.
cons: A bit mismanaged, disorganized, no clear set expectations. Poor communication. A bit antiquated in terms of working remotely/flexibly (even if job allows it, managers do not).

review_title: It's a good job to gain experience
job_title: Care Partner in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Experience, some good workers, patients can be great
cons: Favoritism, underpaid, some lazy nurses, rude parents, floating.

job_title: PCI in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Division of Adolescent Medicine is a fabulous place to work! Very dedicated staff and diverse patient population.
cons: 6 paid holidays, very slim benefits package, and most programs are grant funded (often shaky stability).

job_title: IT Senior Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Competitive salary, great benefits, dedicated and brilliant professionals.
cons: Politics can be challenging at times, and as a non-profit, bonuses and profit-sharing are not part of the picture.

review_title: Amazing place to work, pay could be better.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Critical patients, great learning experiences, great resources
cons: Disconnect between the bedside RN and management at times, lower pay compared to the area

review_title: Such an amazing place to work.
job_title: Language and Cultural Specialist II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: CHLA has the most welcoming attitude that you will experience as an new coming employee. There are many opportunities to move up "the ladder".
cons: The parking lots are very tight.

job_title: Clerk in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Best place to take your child for special care.
cons: The employees were not treated with respect by supervisors.

review_title: Would recommend to someone genuinely interested in the job they're applying for
job_title: Research Associate II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great mission, good people, lots of community engaged work. Overall good culture.
cons: Lots of funding is diverted towards funding departments, less for salaries.

job_title: Clinical Research Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Mission driven, strong leadership team
cons: Incredible amount of red-tape, hard to get things done, systems between TSRI, CHLA and USC are not designed to work together

job_title: Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Health care is some of the best provided.
cons: Management's inability to communicate to staff and their unwillingness to listen.

review_title: Great place to learn and kick-start your career. People are great.
job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Always feel like someone is there to help and teach. Great diversity in skills acquired.
cons: Pay doesn't match to equivalent positions in neighboring hospitals.

review_title: It depends on what department you work in.
job_title: Psychotherapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great for trainees, great exposure to multiple areas.
cons: not great for regular staff if you are not in the main hospital, not much work-life balance.

review_title: A fantastic mission but mediocre management
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: You can feel good about a fantastic mission and lots of truly dedicated, caring coworkers.
cons: Disorganization at the management level and lots of management turnover.

job_title: CNA in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great hospital and good environment
cons: Very small yearly raises (50 cents at most) and the raise didn’t go up when minimum wage got increased in LA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The cafeteria Is delicious, clean facility, colors make you happy. Decent pay great benefits
cons: Management could use some work not enough training time. Too much gossip

job_title: Postdoctoral Psychology Fellow in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great atmosphere, positive attitudes, lots of interdisciplinary work, people are passionate for working with underserved populations
cons: Can be very emotionally taxing in working with the populations

job_title: Physician Strategist
pros: Entire team of professionals working hard to improve care and workflow for their patients. Everyone was working hard to do their part to make transition successful.
cons: Long flight from east coast

job_title: Volunteer Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I have been volunteering at this hospital for about 4 years now. I absolutely love the environment, everyone is friendly and always smiling. Great staff everywhere.
cons: Volunteering on weekends can feel lonely

review_title: It was an amazing training experience with knowledgeable and supportive staff.
job_title: Psychology Predoctoral in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good reputation, excellent resources great clientele.
cons: The salary could have been more competitive.

job_title: Administrative Intern in Vancouver, BC
pros: Good people to work with.
cons: Did not learn very much. No room for advancement beyond intern.

job_title: Operations Supervisor in Vancouver, BC
pros:
The work we do is incredible!
Overall great culture as you walk around the hospital
Competitive Salary
cons: Disorganization in C-Suite as a result of new CEO

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great atmosphere and great coworkers to work with. Many are dedicated to this mission.
cons: The pay for research staff is not as comparable to other hospitals.

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very supportive research institution. Nice people and great location.
cons: A very small institution that is cut off from its affiliate university (USC).

review_title: It is a very great place to work at
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: All PI work at USC medical school.  They are great.  Co-workers are friendly and helpful.
cons: They need more research funding

job_title: Patient Assistant Liaison in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Love the quality of care given to patients by the physicians
cons: Not enough physicians too many patients, who love to come to childrens hospital.

review_title: Great place to work at , great place for grown
job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Teaching hospital, supportive facility, great staff
cons: Lower hourly rate in comparison to competitors

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: great environment, fun place to work
cons: pay, its very busy place to work

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Staff are motivated by hospital mission.
cons: Low pay and non-union; benefits not competitive compared to other hospitals.

job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in Canoga Park, CA
pros: Excellent satisfation because of helping others.
cons: I dont really have anything bad to say about the hospital

job_title: Surg Tech in Los Angeles, CA
pros: CHLA  has gone above and beyond to show that they treat kids better
cons: I have nothing to say negative about CHLA

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great pay, hospital,  and benefits
cons: Management is always out to fire you

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing place to work, easy on boarding process.
cons: Some positions require parking at LA City College, you have to shuttle to the hospital.

job_title: Pediatrician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: See entire range of pediatric pathology, very diverse, great learning experience.
cons: Large organization, rapidly expanding, cumbersome EMR, high volume, large workload

job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great coworkers who love working with children
cons: Lack of leadership support, too old school...

review_title: Good if you get a nice boss
job_title: Research Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Amazing coworkers, everyone is nice to one another
- Decent health insurance
cons: - not enough opportunities of growth

job_title: Director in Tarzana, CA
pros: Great place to receive care for your children and great place to work!!
cons: All excellent!!!!!!! Nothing negative to report.

job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Helping the children get well.
cons: No interaction with the hospital staff

job_title: Process Improvement Intern in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good scope for learning
cons: Too many people with same roles in management

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing place to be a part of.
cons: Location is nowhere near where I'll be moving too.

job_title: Administrative Secretary in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Some departments are better than others to work
cons: The bad is horrible but the good is good.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very helpful HR dept hiring process was smooth.. also  great environment for children
cons: Management is not very helpful

job_title: Staff RN in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Nurses are protected with good nurse to patient ratios
cons: Human Resources department is not very professional

review_title: Excellent professional opportunity with limited growth
job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, flexible schedule, great teammates
cons: Flawed leadership, limited mobility, lack of transparency

job_title: Student Researcher in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Really nice place to work, lots of experience
cons: more like volunteer work so there was no money

review_title: Excellent Salary, Positive and Supportive Staff
job_title: Clinical Social Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent Clinical Supervision & Learning Environment
cons: Commute into Hollywood area can get tiresome.

job_title: Research Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great people, awesome atmosphere, great at getting you involved.
cons: Hard to break in to full time jobs.

job_title: in North Hollywood, CA
pros: Opportunity to learn and advance.
cons: Extremely heavy workload.  Supported a 10 person team.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good job, they really care about the patients, family and employees.
cons: Employees have to pay for parking

job_title: Senior Clinical Laboratory Scientist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Working as a community with people with the same ideals
cons: Need more staffing in lab

job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Self scheduling, decent time off
cons: Moderate Pay, poor retirement plan

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Vista, CA
pros: Great experience to work
cons: It is in Los Angeles County

job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great mission and great people to work with.
cons: None that I can think of at this moment

review_title: Don't belive the fake reviews with 4 or 5 stars - This place is in deep trouble
job_title: Research Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent doctors, nurses and researchers that serves the the hospital in LA community.
cons: Mass exodus of the C-Suite & senior executives.

job_title: Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits are really great
cons: There's a lot of office politics

job_title: Registered Nurse in Lake Forest Park, WA
pros: The Kids and fellow front line staff.
cons: Management and Administration does not respect the work of the frontline staff.  This hospital NEEDS a union to help support and defend the frontline staff.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Not a place for research and scientist career
cons: A lot of equipments are too old to functionally work and CHLA allows PI pays lower than NIH grade wage to Postdoc

job_title: Research Compliance Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: equitable pay for the field, however higher work hours and expectations
cons: No supervision or ability to offer growth/advancement. disorganized. No work/life balance.

job_title: Research Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: 401k, Visa sponsorship, not much otherwise
cons: No holidays, really slow within system, rare chances of promotion within, internal politics

job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Previous leadership was supportive to the staff.
cons: New Leadership doesn't support employees.
